--- title: "Foretaste of Julia Code" page-layout: article jupyter: julia-1.11 --- Julia is a high-level, high-performance programming language primarily designed for numerical and scientific computing. Its syntax is familiar to users of other technical computing environments, while its flexibility and performance make it an excellent choice for a wide range of applications. In this section, we will look at a few simple examples to illustrate some core features of Julia and demonstrate its intuitive and powerful design. ## Variables ### Simple Assignment In Julia, you can assign values to variables directly: ::: {#33c6fa23 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} x = 1 # Assign an integer to x 2x # The result of 2 * x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=85} ``` 2 ``` ::: ::: ### Mathematical Operations You can also perform mathematical operations directly on variables: ::: {#f521368a .cell execution_count=2} ``` {.julia .cell-code} x = sqrt(2) # Assign the square root of 2 to x x # Output the value of x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=86} ``` 1.4142135623730951 ``` ::: ::: ### Using Unicode Julia allows you to use Unicode characters in your code, which makes it more expressive: ::: {#9d8d300a .cell execution_count=3} ``` {.julia .cell-code} # Unicode is great x = âˆš(2) # Square root symbol for 2 x # The value of x is the square root of 2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=87} ``` 1.4142135623730951 ``` ::: ::: ### Custom Variable Names Julia even allows using emojis for variable names: ::: {#7ee2e7a1 .cell execution_count=4} ``` {.julia .cell-code} ðŸ˜„ = sqrt(2) # Assign the square root of 2 to the emoji variable 2ðŸ˜„ # Result of 2 times ðŸ˜„ ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=88} ``` 2.8284271247461903 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-note} Visit the list of [Unicode Input](https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/unicode-input/) for more examples. ::: ## Functions ### Simple Function Definition In Julia, you can define a function using the `function` keyword: ::: {#5a9a5b90 .cell execution_count=5} ``` {.julia .cell-code} # this is a function function f(x) return 2x + 1 # Return a value that is double x plus 1 end ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=89} ``` f (generic function with 2 methods) ``` ::: ::: To evaluate a function, simply call it with an argument: ::: {#6e0907ad .cell execution_count=6} ``` {.julia .cell-code} f(2) # Output: 5 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=90} ``` 5 ``` ::: ::: ### Anonymous Functions Julia also supports anonymous functions (functions without a name), which are often used for short operations: ::: {#a455f0b5 .cell execution_count=7} ``` {.julia .cell-code} # This is also a function g(x) = 2x + 1 # A shorthand for defining a function g(2) # Output: 5 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=91} ``` 5 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#52636546 .cell execution_count=8} ``` {.julia .cell-code} # Another example with anonymous function h = x -> 2x^2 # Function definition using the arrow syntax h(1) # Output: 2, since 2 * 1^2 = 2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=92} ``` 2 ``` ::: ::: ### Function Priority and Operator Precedence In some cases, you need to be cautious about operator precedence: ::: {#d8378bd8 .cell execution_count=9} ``` {.julia .cell-code} # Be careful of operator priorities h(1 + 1) # The correct evaluation is 2 * (1+1)^2 = 8 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=93} ``` 8 ``` ::: ::: ## Side Effects In Julia, functions can have **side effects**, meaning they modify variables or objects outside the scope of the function. Hereâ€™s an example: ### Mutating Vectors Let's consider the following vector: ::: {#167271be .cell execution_count=10} ``` {.julia .cell-code} x = [1, 3, 12] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=94} ``` 3-element Vector{Int64}: 1 3 12 ``` ::: ::: You can access an element of the vector like this: ::: {#55f393dc .cell execution_count=11} ``` {.julia .cell-code} x[2] # Output: 3, the second element of the array ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=95} ``` 3 ``` ::: ::: To update an element, simply reassign it: ::: {#a97e5999 .cell execution_count=12} ``` {.julia .cell-code} x[2] = 5 # Changes the second element to 5 x # Now x = [1, 5, 12] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=96} ``` 3-element Vector{Int64}: 1 5 12 ``` ::: ::: ### Side Effects in Functions If you mutate data inside a function, it will have side effects. For example, consider this function: ::: {#7dbe95f5 .cell execution_count=13} ``` {.julia .cell-code} function f(x, y) x[1] = 42 # Mutates x y = 7 + sum(x) # New binding for y, no mutation return y end a = [4, 5, 6] b = 3 println("f($a, $b) = ", f(a, b)) # f modifies 'a' but not 'b' println("a = ", a, " # a[1] is changed to 42 by f") println("b = ", b, " # b remains unchanged") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` f([4, 5, 6], 3) = 60 a = [42, 5, 6] # a[1] is changed to 42 by f b = 3 # b remains unchanged ``` ::: ::: ### The Bang Convention When a function has side effects, it's a good practice to use the `!` symbol at the end of the function's name. This is called the **bang convention**, and it signals that the function mutates its arguments: ::: {#52d49567 .cell execution_count=14} ``` {.julia .cell-code} function put_at_second_place!(x, value) x[2] = value return nothing # No explicit return, it's just a side effect end x = [1, 3, 12] println("x[2] before: ", x[2]) put_at_second_place!(x, 5) # Mutates x println("x[2] after: ", x[2]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` x[2] before: 3 x[2] after: 5 ``` ::: ::: ### Caution with Slices Be cautious when passing slices of arrays to functions. Modifying a slice can also modify the original array: ::: {#80446a69 .cell execution_count=15} ``` {.julia .cell-code} put_at_second_place!(x[1:3], 15) # Be careful with slices println("x[2] after slice mutation: ", x[2]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` x[2] after slice mutation: 5 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-warning} When a function modifies mutable objects, it can lead to unexpected results. Always be mindful of what is passed into functions. ::: ## Methods Julia supports multiple methods for the same function name, which allows for more flexible and dynamic behavior. Here's an example: ### Method Overloading You can define several methods for the same function with different types: ::: {#d7e99b56 .cell execution_count=16} ``` {.julia .cell-code} Î£(x::Float64, y::Float64) = 2x + y # Method for Float64 inputs ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=100} ``` Î£ (generic function with 1 method) ``` ::: ::: Calling the function: ::: {#971f74c5 .cell execution_count=17} ``` {.julia .cell-code} Î£(2.0, 3.0) # Output: 7.0 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=101} ``` 7.0 ``` ::: ::: If you call `Î£` with arguments that don't match the types, Julia will throw an error: ::: {#8dfca22a .cell execution_count=18} ``` {.julia .cell-code} Î£(2, 3.0) # Error: no method matching Î£(::Int64, ::Float64) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
MethodError: no method matching Î£(::Int64, ::Float64)
The function `Î£` exists, but no method is defined for this combination of argument types.

Closest candidates are:
  Î£(::Float64, ::Float64)
   @ Main In[100]:1


Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope
   @ In[102]:1
``` ::: ::: ::: ### Multiple Methods for Different Types You can define more methods that work with different types: ::: {#dd838b07 .cell execution_count=19} ``` {.julia .cell-code} Ï†(x::Number, y::Number) = 2x - y # General method for numbers Ï†(x::Int, y::Int) = 2x * y # Method for integers Ï†(x::Float64, y::Float64) = 2x + y # Method for Float64 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=103} ``` Ï† (generic function with 3 methods) ``` ::: ::: ### Method Dispatch Example Julia will select the appropriate method based on the argument types: ::: {#b8d3324f .cell execution_count=20} ``` {.julia .cell-code} println("Ï†(2, 3.0) = ", Ï†(2, 3.0)) # Uses general method println("Ï†(2, 3) = ", Ï†(2, 3)) # Uses the integer method println("Ï†(2.0, 3.0) = ", Ï†(2.0, 3.0)) # Uses the Float64 method ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Ï†(2, 3.0) = 1.0 Ï†(2, 3) = 12 Ï†(2.0, 3.0) = 7.0 ``` ::: ::: ## Iterators In Julia, iterators allow you to loop through collections in a memory-efficient way. Hereâ€™s an example of using `1:5` as an iterator: ::: {#c314704f .cell execution_count=21} ``` {.julia .cell-code} for i in 1:5 println(i) end ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 1 2 3 4 5 ``` ::: ::: This prints the numbers from 1 to 5. You can also iterate through ranges and collections: ::: {#466522e9 .cell execution_count=22} ``` {.julia .cell-code} for i in [10, 20, 30] println(i) end ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 10 20 30 ``` ::: ::: ### Working with Lazy Collections Juliaâ€™s `Iterators` package allows for lazy collections, where values are computed on demand. Hereâ€™s an example: ::: {#ebca6e24 .cell execution_count=23} ``` {.julia .cell-code} using Base.Iterators: cycle for i in cycle([1, 2, 3]) println(i) if i == 3 break end end ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 1 2 3 ``` ::: ::: This loops over the values 1, 2, and 3, repeating as a cycle. ## Types and Type Stability ### Type Stability Julia has **type stability** for fast compilation and execution. When writing functions, it's important to ensure that the type of the return value can be determined without ambiguity. Here's an example: ::: {#a15f9171 .cell execution_count=24} ``` {.julia .cell-code} function f(x) if x > 0 return 1 else return 0.0 end end println(typeof(f(2))) # Output: Int64 println(typeof(f(-2))) # Output: Float64 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Int64 Float64 ``` ::: ::: Julia is dynamically typed, but ensuring **type stability** within functions helps the compiler optimize code for better performance. ::: {.callout-tip} For better performance, always try to ensure type stability in your functions. This can be achieved by making the return type predictable, from the types of input variables and not their values. ::: ## Exercise ### Least Squares Regression Line We propose a first exercise about [simple linear regression](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_linear_regression). The data are excerpted from this [example](https://www.ncl.ac.uk/webtemplate/ask-assets/external/maths-resources/statistics/regression-and-correlation/simple-linear-regression.html) and saved into [data.csv](data.csv). We propose an [ordinary least squares](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ordinary_least_squares) formulation which is a type of [linear least squares](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_least_squares) method for choosing the unknown parameters in a linear regression model by the principle of least squares: minimizing the sum of the squares of the differences between the observed dependent variable (values of the variable being observed) in the input dataset and the output of the (linear) function of the independent variable. Given a set ofÂ $m$Â data pointsÂ $y_{1}$, $y_{2}$, $\dots$, $y_{m}$,Â consisting of experimentally measured values taken atÂ $m$Â valuesÂ $x_{1}$, $x_{2}$, $\dots$, $x_{m}$Â of an independent variable ($x_i$Â may be scalar or vector quantities), and given a model functionÂ $y=f(x,\beta),$Â withÂ $\beta =(\beta_{1},\beta_{2},\dots ,\beta_{n})$,Â it is desired to find the parametersÂ $\beta_j$ such that the model function "best" fits the data. In linear least squares, linearity is meant to be with respect to parametersÂ $\beta_j$, so $$ f(x, \beta) = \sum_{j=1}^n \beta_j\, \varphi_j(x). $$ In general, the functions $\varphi_j$ may be nonlinear. However, we consider linear regression, that is $$ f(x, \beta) = \beta_1 + \beta_2 x. $$ Ideally, the model function fits the data exactly, so $$ y_i = f(x_i, \beta) $$ for all $i=1, 2, \dots, m$. This is usually not possible in practice, as there are more data points than there are parameters to be determined. The approach chosen then is to find the minimal possible value of the sum of squares of the residuals $$ r_i(\beta) = y_i - f(x_i, \beta), \quad i=1, 2, \dots, m $$ so to minimize the function $$ S(\beta) = \sum_{i=1}^m r_i^2(\beta). $$ In the linear least squares case, the residuals are of the form $$ r(\beta) = y - X\, \beta $$ with $y = (y_i)_{1\le i\le m} \in \mathbb{R}^m$ and $X = (X_{ij})_{1\le i\le m, 1\le j\le n} \in \mathrm{M}_{mn}(\mathbb{R})$, where $X_{ij} = \varphi_j(x_i)$. Since we consider linear regression, the $i$-th row of the matrix $X$ is given by $$ X_{i[:]} = [1 \quad x_i]. $$ The objective function may be written $$ S(\beta) = {\Vert y - X\, \beta \Vert}^2 $$ where the norm is the usual $2$-norm. The solution to the linear least squares problem $$ \underset{\beta \in \mathbb{R}^n}{\mathrm{minimize}}\, {\Vert y - X\, \beta \Vert}^2 $$ is computed by solving the *normal equation* $$ X^\top X\, \beta = X^\top y, $$ where $X^\top$ denotes the transpose of $X$. ### Questions To answer the questions you need to import the following packages. ::: {#2e72915a .cell execution_count=25} ``` {.julia .cell-code} using DataFrames using CSV using Plots ``` ::: You also need to download the csv file. Click on the following image. 1. Using the packages `DataFrames.jl` and `CSV.jl`, load the dataset from [data/introduction/data.csv](data/introduction/data.csv) and save the result into a variable named `dataset`. ::: {#f6c66f2b .cell execution_count=26} ``` {.julia .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Show the answer"} path = "data/introduction/data.csv" # update depending on the location of your file dataset = DataFrame(CSV.File(path)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=110} ```{=html}
5Ã—2 DataFrame
RowTimeMass
Int64Int64

416210
520240
``` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-note} Do not hesitate to visit the documentation of `CSV.jl` and `DataFrames.jl`. ::: 2. Using the package `Plot.jl`, plot the data. ::: {.callout-tip collapse="true"} ## Hint Use `names(dataset)` to get the list of data names. If `Time` is a name you can access to the associated data by `dataset.Time`. ::: ::: {#887aa830 .cell execution_count=27} ``` {.julia .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Show the answer"} plt = plot( dataset.Time, dataset.Mass, seriestype=:scatter, legend=false, xlabel="Time", ylabel="Mass" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=111} ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: 1. Create the matrix $X$, the vector $\beta$ and solve the normal equation with the operator [`Base.\`](https://tinyurl.com/juliadoc-base-backslash). ::: {.callout-tip collapse="true"} ## Hint Use `ones(m)` to generate a vector of 1 of length $m$. ::: ::: {#ff0fb655 .cell execution_count=28} ``` {.julia .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Show the answer"} m = length(dataset.Time) X = [ones(m) dataset.Time] y = dataset.Mass Î² = X\y ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=112} ``` 2-element Vector{Float64}: 11.506493506493449 12.207792207792208 ``` ::: ::: 4. Plot the linear model on the same plot as the data. Use the `plot!` function. See the [basic concepts for plotting](https://docs.juliaplots.org/stable/basics/#Basic-Concepts). ::: {#b469f76c .cell execution_count=29} ``` {.julia .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Show the answer"} x = [5, 20] y = Î²[1] .+ Î²[2]*x plot!(plt, x, y) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=113} ```{=html} ``` ::: :::
